titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection
China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Nungshitula Jamir and Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 4, 2019 at 22:00

did.unittitle: China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection
did.abstract: The China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection is an open collection. It currently contains material from more than 325 individuals, primarily Protestant missionaries to China. The time period covered is approximately from 1834 to 1998. The China Records Project was initiated by the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A in 1968. The aim of the project was to insure the preservation of the personal records of former missionaries to China and to provide a central repository where these papers would be available to historians. The Yale Divinity School Library was chosen as this central repository in 1969 and has continued to solicit and accept China-related papers since that time.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: China Records Project Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection (RG 8), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The China Records Project was initiated by the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A in 1968. The aim of the project was to insure the preservation of the personal records of former missionaries to China and to provide a central repository where these papers would be available to historians. The Yale Divinity School Library was chosen as this central repository in 1969 and has continued to solicit and accept China-related papers since that time.

The first Protestant missionary to China was Robert Morrison, who arrived in 1807. Elijah Coleman Bridgman was the first American missionary to China, sent by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions in 1829. Protestant missionaries were active in China until ca. 1950 when they were forced to leave by the new Communist government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of more than 380 boxes, with no individual accounting for more than three linear feet. Some collections that were formerly part of this record group have now been given separate record group numbers.

The papers in the first series of this collection are arranged alphabetically by name. When the information was available, each missionary's sending agency, geographical location in China and period of service have been noted. A key to abbreviations used to represent the mission sending agencies is given below. The designation "L" in the indications of period of service means that these are approximate dates derived from listings in available copies of the Directory of Protestant Missions in China (1902, 1904-05, 1908-11, 1916, 1921, 1923-24, 1926-30, 1932-36, 1940, 1950). An asterisk following the name of an individual means that at least a portion of the papers of that individual are available on microfilm (and therefore accessible via Interlibrary Loan)and through the Adam Matthew "China Through Western Eyes" database: http://www.researchsource.amdigital.co.uk/ASChina.

Some photographs in the collection have been digitized and are available through the Internet Mission Photography Archive (IMPA) - http://www.usc.edu/isd/archives/arc/digarchives/mission/. If availability in IMPA is indicated, search the IMPA database using the name of the individual, e.g., search for "Edward Abbott Papers."

The records in this collection include biographical information, correspondence, diaries and journals, writings, printed material, tape recordings, artifacts, photographs and maps. The medical, educational and evangelical work of both men and women missionaries in China is reflected in the material. Social issues such as footbinding, opium reform, education of women, cruelty to animals and child labor are also touched upon. The material is particularly valuable for the descriptions of daily missionary life and work which it provides. Missionary opinion about major social and political issues is less prevalent in the material, although personal accounts of some political events (such as the Boxer Rebellion and the internment of missionaries by the Japanese) are given.
The Oral History Transcripts of Series II are from the China Missionaries Oral History Project conducted at Claremont Graduate School in Claremont, CA in the early 1970s.
For a full list of personal papers that are part of the China Records Project see: https://web.library.yale.edu/divinity/china-papers.
Abbreviations for missions agencies used in this finding aid:

list.item: ABCFM -American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions
ChCC -China Continuation Committee of the National Missionary Conference
LCMS -Lutheran Church Missouri Synod; pre 1947 MELCM; pre 1927 ELSM
RCUS -Reformed Church in the United States
UCMS -United Christian Missionary Society (Disciples of Christ)
WFMS -Women's Foreign Missionary Society of Methodist Episcopal Church

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Several sets of papers in this collection have been microfilmed and are now also available in digital format at http://www.researchsource.amdigital.co.uk/ASChina. The Adam Matthew digital database is accessible only to the Yale community; microfilm can be requested via interlibrary loan. Individuals whose papers are available on microfilm and digitally are noted with an asterisk.

Abbott, Edward

Collection of 57 photographs taken in China between 1896 and 1900 at various Episcopal missions, medical and educational institutions, churches, incl. St. John's College, Shanghai; Boone School, Wuchang; St. Peter's Hospital, Wuchang; St. Peter's Church, Hankow. Buildings, faculty, students, clergy, etc. represented. Also of interest: Imperial Examination cells at Nanking, Chinese Prayer Book Revision Committee. Following individuals are included in photos: Ingle, Pott, Partridge, Thomson, Graves, Huntington, Roots, Littell, faculty of St. John's College, 1897. (Some photos available in IMPA: http://www.usc.edu/isd/archives/arc/digarchives/mission)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: 1869 Born in Meriden, N.H. 1890 Graduated with honors from Oberlin College;; 1894 Sailed for China to work for the Christian and Missionary Alliance; 1896 Married Rev. Matthew Brown Birrell; 1941 Finished missionary service, returned to U.S.; 1964 Died

did.unittitle: Typescript ms.: "Frances Catlin Birrell 1869-1964 An Autobiography"; Biography of her daughter Agnes Catlin Birrell
Birrell, Matthew Brown

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: 1869 Born in Glasgow, Scotland; 1891 Entered Missionary Training College in New York City; 1892 Sailed to China and started work in Han Shan; 1896 Married Frances Howe Catlin ; 1941 Finished missionary service, returned to U.S.; 1957 Died; Matthew Brown Birrell ministered in Peking and Wuhu; second term, Changsha in Hunan;third and fourth terms, Wuchang; fifth term, Changteh. After teaching at the St. Paul Bible Institute for two years in the U.S., in 1937 he and Frances returned to Wuchang, until they were evacuated in 1938 at the outbreak of the Chinese-Japanese War. They were sent to Hong Kong, then Shanghai, returning to the U.S. in 1941, where they retired at the Mission Colony in Glendale, California.

did.unittitle: Bound ms.: "Matthew Brown Birrell 1869-1957 An Autobiography"
Bishop, Merlin A.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: Went to China in 1935; served as administrator and taught trades at Christian Herald Orphanages started by Emily Hartwell; oversaw property of Fukien Christian University until forced to leave by Japanese occupation; 1944-1945 in Chungking, in charge of United Clearing Board, which handled U.S. money coming into China for missions and relief work; 1945-1948 YMCA industrial training secretary in Shanghai; left China 1948. Bishop was the husband of Eunice Smith Bishop; see also YDSL Record Group No. 5, Edward Huntington Smith Family Papers.

Burch, Clarence Arthur and Miriam Stuart Hewes

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: After marrying Mr. and Mrs. Burch began missionary work in China in 1906 in Wuhu. From 1906-1918, they worked under the Advent Christian Missions, and from 1918-1940 under the United Christian Mission Society. They experienced the Civil War of China (1911-1912), the Revolution (1926-1928) and the Japanese War (1936-1940). The Burches had four daughters, one of whom died tragically in her early twenties, after undergoing surgery. The Burches returned to the U.S., and Mr. Burch traveled for the UCMS. for two years. In 1942, he became an assistant professor at Texas Christian University, earning his M.A. from the university in 1947.

Gundlach, Adelaide

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info.: Gundlach (1890-1987) was born in Rochester, NY, daughter of a minister in the German Reformed Church. Following attendance at a business college and involvement with the YWCA, she entered Oberlin College in 1914. She went to Ginling College, Nanking, in 1918 and worked as Secretary of the college for four years before returning to the U.S. From 1923-1955 she served as Registrar, with expanded responsibilities, at Berea College in Kentucky.

Hanks, Emma Jane (Foster Petach)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog info: Emma Jane Foster was an exchange student at Lingnan University in 1935-1936. She received her B.A. from Penn State in 1937, her Masters in Nursing from Yale School of Nursing in 1940, and worked for the Minneapolis Nursing Association. She served on the medical team of the Flying Tigers American Volunteer Group in China, where she met and married John "Pete" Petach, one of the airmen, in February 1942. Petach died in a bombing raid in July 1942 and Emma Jane returned to the U.S. where she gave birth to their child Joan Claire Petach in February 1943. She continued her nursing career and later married Fletcher Hanks in 1964.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: 1895 Born in Maryland; 1916 Graduated from Johns Hopkins University; 1917 Married Lily May Anderson; 1918 MA-B.D. from Drew Theological Seminary, D.D. from Western Md. College; 1921 Left to be a missionary in Foochow, China under the Methodist Board of Foreign Missions; 1951 Left China permanently; 1970 Moved to a retirement home; Hayes worked in South China until a furlough in 1937, where he supervised the development of hospitals, schools, and churches. He returned to China in 1938, and his wife joined him nine years later, when she finally was granted permission to return. Two years after the Communists took over the area, the Hayes left China, but were only permitted to take their hand luggage with them.

Hebbert, Virginia*

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: ACM, Anking, Anhwei,1946-1950; Born on December 30, 1911 in South Dakota, Virginia Hebbert was educated at Syracuse University and the Columbia University School of Social Work. From 1933 to 1946 she served as a Caseworker and Case Work Supervisor in child caring institutions and social agencies. In 1946 she was appointed as a missionary under the Episcopal Church to start a medical social work department at St. James Hospital, Anking, Anhwei Province. She spent two years in language study - six months at the China Inland Mission Language School in Anking and one and a half years at Hua Wen Hsueh, Hsiao, Peking. In addition to her responsibilities in connection with St. James Hospital, Hebbert also taught English part-time at An Ta University. The Anking area came under Communist control in April, 1949 but St. James Hospital was able to carry on with its work. Following her departure from China in December, 1950 Hebbert taught at universities in the United States and served in the Philippines from 1955 to 1967. See Box 250, Folder 24 for additional biographical information.

Herman, Theodore

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: Herman taught at Shanghai American School 1936-1939, worked in the anti-Japanese underground in Shanghai, did publicity for Indusco in Hong Kong, organized industrial cooperatives, and served with the Friend Centre in Shanghai until interned by the Japanese in 1942 at the Haiphong Road Camp. His wife (Chen Shih-ying) was warden of the Friends Receiving Home for lost children in Shanghai. After Herman was repatriated to the U.S. in 1943 he returned to West China with the U.S. Office of War and was reunited with his wife. After the war he served with the UN Relief and Rehabilitation Administration for three years in Shanghai and Jiangsi.

Huang, Juanita Byrd

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info.: Juanita Byrd Huang was a Southern Baptist missionary who taught English at the University of Shanghai from 1929 until her marriage to a Chinese in 1946. The Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board disassociated itself from her at the time of her marriage. After a furlough in 1936 she returned to China and when the Japanese occupied Shanghai she was temporarily sent with other missionary women and children to the Philippines. Returning to Shanghai, she continued to teach in Shanghai, though part of the university had migrated to West China. Following a period in a Japanese internment camp at Chapei Centre, she was repatriated to the U.S. She returned to China in 1946 and married Claude Huang. They remained in China until 1957 when Claude was finally allowed to leave the country via Hong Kong.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: 1919 Born in St. Matthews, S.C.; 1940 B.S. in Chemistry from Johns Hopkins University; 1943 Graduated from Johns Hopkins School of Medicine; 1948 Took job as head of the Department of Pathology of the Cheeloo College of Medicine in Jinan, Shandong; Dr. Iverson has spent a lifetime working in developing areas of Asia, including China, the Philippines and India. In 1952-1954, she spent a year as a visiting professor at the University of the Philippines, helping the university to restructure its Department of Pathology. From 1950-1960, Dr. Iverson was Senior Pathologist for the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington, D.C. In 1960, she traveled to India, where she started a medical system specifically designed for the country.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: LUM, 1924-1953, primarily in Honan until 1949 May and in Hong Kong, 1949 May - 1953 Feb.

did.unittitle: Papers consist of more than 85 photocopies of mimeographed circular letters. These substantive letters (some ten or more pages) date from 1947 until 1958 and provide valuable detailed information about the Church in China in the years leading up to and following the Communist takeover. Lee had extensive correspondence with Chinese and Western individuals in China while he was working in Hong Kong and received numerous Christian periodicals from China, from which he quotes in his circular letters. He provides specific information des- cribing the work of missionaries who remained in China following the Communist takeover and regarding the status of schools and hospitals in the interior. He provides information about Church activities and conferences in China such as the Enlarged Council of the Lutheran Church in China meeting in January, 1951 and the Peking Christian Conference of April, 1951 where the Accusation Movement was inaugurated. These letters are written from a clearly anti-Communist stance. They provide extensive information regarding the development of the Three Self Movement in China.

Lewis, Neil and Alice

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: Alice Hay Lewis (1900-2001) and Neil Huntington Lewis (1895-1980) were graduates of Oberlin College and Neil received a medical degree from Western Reserve. They went to China in 1925 as ABCFM missionaries, stationed at the American Board Hospital, Foochow. They returned to the U.S. in 1932, expecting to return after their furlough, but their support was withdrawn due to the Depression. Neil practiced medicine in California from 1933.

did.unittitle: Compilation of family correspondence: including regarding departure to China, supplies taken, river trip to Foochow, language study, trips to Ingtai, Kuliang, Pagoda Anchorage, birth of daughter Grace Luana, home robbed by soldiers (1927), difficulties at the hospital, political unrest, move to Ingtai, birth of son Philip, summers at Kuliang, Japanese attack, return to Foochow

Compilation of family corresopndence: including regarding reunion with Neil's parents in Shanghai, journey to U.S., Neil's studies at Columbia, time at Auburndale, MA, mission reports and letters to friends, decision of ABCFM that family should not return to China due to financial situation, move to California, birth of daughter Emily.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: MES Soochow, Shanghai (1876-1923); Alvin Pierson Parker was a prominent Southern Methodist missionary - a teacher, preacher, writer, editor, and translator. He was a founder of the Buffington Institute in Soochow and later taught at the Anglo-Chinese College in Shanghai (1896-1905). He wrote Chinese textbooks for various subjects, wrote for mission periodicals, was a member of the Shanghai Bible Translation Committee.

Peet, Lyman Burt

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: Lyman Burt Peet (1809-) graduated from Middlebury College in 1834, and entered Andover Seminary. There he discovered a call to missionary work and in 1839 married Rebecca Sherrill; later that same year, the couple sailed for Bangkok, Siam, where they worked for six years among the Chinese people there. After that, the Peets were sent to start the mission in Foochow, China, where they began work in 1847. A year after his wife's death in 1856, Lyman Peet returned to the U.S. and married his second wife, Hannah Plimpton.

Shepherd, Clara Sargent and George W.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: Clara Sargent went to China in 1919 as the first female doctor to serve in the field of public health. She worked with the National Council on Health Education and served on the faculty of the Women's College of Physical Education in Shanghai, which later became a department of Ginling College in Nanking. She promoted public health campaigns in China and helped in writing health textbooks for Chinese government schools. In 1921, she married the Rev. Dr. George Shepherd, and served as a physician and public health director under the ABCFM in Shaowu and Foochow in Fukien. She and Rev. Shepherd were evacuated from China shortly before Pearl Harbor.

Simester, Edith (Roeder)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog info: Edith Simester Roeder (1902-1991) was born in Foochow, China where her parents were missionaries. Following her education in the U.S. she taught at the Anglo-Chinese College, a Methodist institution in Fukien from ca. 1930 to 1946. Unable to return to China, she taught at Scarritt College, served in in Brazil for three years, and then was in charge of an Adult Literacy Program in South Korea until 1960. She married Paul Roeder in 1961.

Stone, Mary

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Mary Stone (Shi Meiyu, 1873-1954) was one of the first three Chinese women to obtain a medical degree in the U.S. Returning to China in 1896 she served a Methodist mission hospital for 25 years, with her friend Ida Kahn (Kang Cheng) and American missionary Jennie Hughes. In the 1920s Mary and Jennie resigned from the Methodist Women's Foreign Missionary Society and founded the nondenominational Shanghai Bethel Mission.

did.unittitle: 20 mounted photographs depict Mary Stone, Jennie Hughes, colleagues, the Bethel Hospital in Shanghai, nursing and midwifery graduates, war orphans, a Bethel evangelistic band meeting in Hong Kong, Bethel Mission seminaries and conference.

Stucki, John Calvin and Marie

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: RCUS, Peking (1924-1926), Yochow City, Hunan (1926-1927); John Calvin Stucki, medical missionary for the Reformed Church in the U.S. became superintendent of the Hoy Memorial Hospital at Yochow City, Hunan in April 1926 following a period of training in Peking. Yochow City was taken over by the Kuomintang in August, 1926. In November, the workers at the mission went on strike and students began making demands. In late 1926, educational work was discontinued at the mission and, in January of 1927, the nurses training school at Hoy was forced to close and women and children were evacuated. JCS was held captive by the Nationalists until February when he was permitted to join his wife and return to the U.S.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Clifford Sharp Trimmer and his wife Ruth were American Methodist missionaries stationed in Nanking from the 1920s-1950. C.S. Trimmer was a medical doctor serving the University Hospital in Nanking. He was among the missionaries who stayed in Nanking during the Japanese occupation of the city in 1937-1938. After missionaries were forced to leave China in 1950, the Trimmers served in India and Pakistan from 1953 to 1957.

Tucker, Augustine W. (family)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Augustine Washington Tucker (1883-1958) was an Episcopal medical missionary in Shanghai for more than forty years. His wife, Annie Webb Cheshire (1884-1964), began her missionary service in China in 1909. They were married in 1914 and had seven children: Augustine, Annie, Maria, Joseph, Elizabeth, Sarah, and Beverley. A.W. Tucker's brother Ellis was a professor at St. John's University in Shanghai. His brother Henry St. George Tucker was a missionary in Japan and later Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence of Augustine and Annie Tucker to/from their daughter Elizabeth Toole Tucker (Eddy) as well as other correspondence and memorabilia of Elizabeth, correspondence of her brother Beverley, writings, genealogical and biographical material about the Tucker family, photographs, and collected material.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: From 1929 to 1940 Williams was campus minister and head of the Department of Sociology at Soochow University, located first in Soochow and later in Shanghai. He was active in refugee relief and had responsibility for negotiations with the Japanese on protection of Mission property, 1937-1940. He was Secretary of Missionary Personnel of the Board of Missions of the Methodist Church from 1942 to 1969.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Biog. info: MEFB; born 1904 in Arkansas; graduated from Henderson Brown College (1924), Yale Divinity School (1928), Union Theological Seminary (STM, 1939). Served as YMCA Secretary before leaving for China in 1933. Served at Soochow University and later in Changchow in evangelistic work.

did.unittitle: Correspondence to parents and siblings, incl. re. arrival in China, George's illness with pleurisy, summer vacation in Mokanshan, in Soochow

Correspondence to parents incl. re. work in Changchow, Japanese bombings (1937), furlough in U.S., daughter's contraction of polio following return to China (1939), return to U.S. for treatment at Warm Springs, GA

Correspondence to/from family, incl. re. return to China, work in Shanghai, teaching at Soochow University Law School; family's evacuation to Manila and return to Shanghai, re. unsettled political situation; preparations to return to U.S.
Additional correspondence, incl. letters from Cartwright, Chen, Hanson, Merrill; circular letters of Workman
